Within days, the team confirmed a torn Achilles tendon, one of the toughest injuries for any NFL skill player.The injury occurred on Kittle’s second catch of the night at Lincoln Financial Field. He planted his right foot as he turned upfield and immediately collapsed. The 49ers held on for a 23–19 win, but the locker room mood remained tense as teammates waited for clarity on Kittle’s status.That clarity arrived on January 16, when head coach Kyle Shanahan addressed reporters during his weekly press conference in Santa Clara. Shanahan confirmed Kittle’s surgery went well and hinted at a recovery timeline that may look different than older Achilles cases.“I talked to him through text,” Shanahan said during Friday’s media availability on Jan 16. “He sent a funny picture of himself after surgery to my wife. He seemed to be feeling pretty good. I heard it went great, and it was a successful surgery. He has a chance to come back a lot sooner than we used to think back in the day with Achilles injuries.”Kittle finished the 2025 regular season with 74 receptions for 1,041 yards and eight touchdowns, once again serving as Brock Purdy’s most reliable target in big moments. His absence removes a major red-zone threat and a key blocker from San Francisco’s system. Wide receiver Ricky Pearsall added another update on Jan. 15 during an interview on 95.7 The Game. He said Kittle already appeared upbeat during a FaceTime call.“He’s playing video games already,” Pearsall said. “He’s in good spirits. That’s just George.”The 49ers now turn to Luke Farrell and Jake Tonges at tight end as they prepare to face the Seattle Seahawks in the divisional round on January 18. With Nick Bosa already lost for the season, San Francisco faces growing pressure to stay healthy.No return date has been set yet for Kittle. Still, Shanahan’s update gave the locker room something it needed. Hope.Also Read: George Kittle’s wife, Claire Kittle, was heartbroken and visibly emotional as he went down injured in new footage that has shocked fans

Article Title: Travis Kelce and Dak Prescott net worth comparison: Salary, Contract, Endorsement, and more

Endorsements and off-field income

Travis Kelce and Dak Prescott are two of the most well-known players in the NFL. They have made a lot of money through contracts and other things. Even though they play different positions and in different markets, both of them are among the highest-paid players in the league. Take a deeper look at how their net worths stack up when you look at their salary, contracts, sponsorships, and business moves.According to Celebrity Net Worth, Travis Kelce's net worth is estimated to be around $90 million. He has built it up carefully over more than ten years with the Kansas City Chiefs. And Dak Prescott is also worth over $90 million. His wealth has grown a lot in the last few years because he earned record-breaking contracts with the Dallas Cowboys as a quarterback.While the totals may look the same on paper, the paths to those numbers are extremely different.Kelce entered the NFL in 2013 and earned just under $80 million in salary across his first 10 seasons. His biggest paydays came with a five-year, $46 million extension in 2016 and a two-year, $34.25 million extension signed in 2024, which pushed his career earnings beyond the $100 million mark. For a tight end, Kelce has consistently remained near the top of the pay scale.Prescott’s rise has been far more dramatic. After outperforming expectations as a fourth-round pick, he secured a four-year, $160 million deal in 2021. He then reset the market in 2024 with a four-year, $240 million contract, making him the first NFL player to cross $60 million per year in average salary.Both athletes are quite rich because of endorsements, but Kelce is more famous right now. He makes roughly $5 million a year from working with brands like Nike, McDonald's, State Farm, Bud Light, and others. His fame has grown even more because of his media appearances, his success with podcasts, and his exposure to pop culture.Prescott has also signed big endorsement deals with big brands like Adidas, AT&T, Pepsi, Beats by Dre, and others. His sponsorships have made him more than $50 million over his career, given to the Cowboys' massive global fan base and his status as a franchise quarterback.Kelce’s financial profile extends beyond football and ads. The “New Heights” podcast, co-hosted with his brother Jason Kelce, landed a reported $100 million deal with Amazon’s Wondery, significantly boosting his long-term earning potential. He has also invested in brands like Casa Azul Tequila.Prescott has focused more on traditional investments, real estate, and philanthropy through his Faith Fight Finish Foundation, while continuing to prioritise football earnings.While Dak Prescott clearly leads in salary and contract value, Travis Kelce’s diversified income streams especially media and branding help keep their net worths remarkably close. In short, Prescott dominates the quarterback pay scale, while Kelce maximises star power beyond the field.

Article Title: Inside the emotional locker room message Mike Tomlin delivered before leaving the Steelers
Article Text:
Mike Tomlin ended his 19-year run with the Steelers through a private, emotional locker room message that stunned players and staff. Despite a strong overall record, playoff frustrations pushed him to step away voluntarily for the first time. The decision left the locker room shaken, marked the end of an era in Pittsburgh, and opened the door to a possible broadcasting future.

Mike Tomlin’s farewell reshapes the Steelers future

Mike Tomlin did not walk away quietly. The final words he delivered inside the Pittsburgh locker room landed with the force of a season-ending hit. After nearly two decades of setting the tone for the Pittsburgh Steelers, Tomlin chose honesty over ceremony. The message was private, emotional, and unforgettable. It marked the end of a coaching era few believed would ever truly end.For players, the shock was immediate. Tomlin had never resigned voluntarily at any level. His presence felt permanent, stitched into the fabric of the franchise. Yet on January 13, the room went still when he spoke. According to a team source, Tomlin told them, “You deserve better, and right now I can’t deliver. Someone else has to move the franchise forward.” The words cut deep because they came from a coach who demanded more from himself than anyone else.Tomlin leaves behind numbers most coaches dream of. A 193-112-2 regular season record and a reputation for never posting a losing year. Still, postseason frustration weighed heavily. Seven playoff trips in ten years produced only one win beyond the Wild Card round. For Tomlin, that gap mattered.His standard never softened, even when the résumé stayed elite.The emotional fallout revealed how much he meant. Reports described T.J. Watt fighting tears, while Aaron Rodgers repeated apologies under his breath. One unnamed player summed it up bluntly, saying Tomlin was the only coach men would run through walls for. The city wanted a breakthrough. The locker room wanted it for him even more.Owner Art Rooney II tried to keep the door open. He hoped for one more year. Tomlin declined. Rooney later explained, “Mike indicated that he did not anticipate coaching at least in the near future,” adding that family time and long-delayed personal moments now come first.Though Tomlin still has two years left on his contract, many believe this chapter is final. His voice, however, is not leaving football. FOX executives reportedly admire his sharp insight and signature phrasing. A studio role could follow. For now, the Steelers move forward without the man who defined them, while Tomlin steps away on his own terms, loyal to the standard he lived by.Also Read: Why did Mike Tomlin exit the Pittsburgh Steelers? Pressure from playoff failures marks the end of a historic era
Article Summary: Pittsburgh Steelers coach Mike Tomlin stepped down voluntarily on January 13. Tomlin left with a 193-112-2 regular season record and a reputation for never posting a losing year. The Steelers have made seven playoff trips in ten years, but never beyond the Wild Card round.
